dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amongst the weary tourist families and solitary businessm sits TOM WELLES, middle-aged, hair neat, suit crisp and gray.  He's eating crackers from a cellophane package, sipping soda from a paper cup, watching an ARRIVAL GATE.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GATE
dialogues.text: PASSENGERS arrive: the paunchy, graying men of First Clas leading the pack, except for a handsome YOUNG REPUBLICAN poster boy hurrying along.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE TERMINAL
dialogues.text: Welles gets up and FOLLOWS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles comes outside, squinting in the sun, moving down t sidewalk, looking back over his shoulder... The Young Republican is lead to a waiting LIMO by a DRIVE Welles moves to the nearby TAXI STAND...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles gets in, turning in his seat to watch behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to? Welles keeps watching, sees the limo pull away and pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow that limousine.  Don't get too close, don't let it get too far away.  Just keep with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. The cab set in motion.  Welles takes out cigarettes, lighting one, takes out a small NOTEPAD and makes notatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, listen... you're not supposed to be smoking in here.  I'm sorry, that's company policy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this... every cigarette I smoke, I give you five dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... okay, yeah, that'd be good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of an Art Deco hotel, the driver opens the limousine door and the Young Republican steps out.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: Welles watches from inside the double-parked taxicab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly four-star.  "AD LT MOVIES EVERY ROOM."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is asleep on the bed, full dressed, hands folded across his stomach, snoring lightly, sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits alone at the bar, eating a sandwich, bored. watches some fuzzy ESPN on the t.v., looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles walks across the parking lot, gets into his RENTAL CAR, starts it and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Republican and a GAUDY WOMAN exit the disco, MUSIC THROBBING out from the doors behind them.  They join hand drunk, heading to the street, looking for their limo.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Welles is seated in his parked rental car, raises a CAMER with TELEPHOTO LENS: whir, CLICK, whir, CLICK, whir, CLIC Welles lowers the camera, letting out a yawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The familiar DRONE of flight.  Welles is shoehorned into aisle seat, using tiny utensils to eat his tiny meal. An OLDER WOMAN arrives in the aisle.  Welles picks up his tray, closes his tray table, unbuckling his seatbelt, struggling to get up... finally successful, balancing his tray, letting the woman in to the window seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Welles nods, forcing a smile, sitting back down.  He retu to toiling over his miniature supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles' AIRPLANE ROARS down with a SCREECH, landing light gleaming.  The airport is small, relatively isolated. TITLE:      Harrisburg, Pennsylvania

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers arrive.  Welles is with them, searching the fe PEOPLE waiting in the terminal hallway.  Welles smiles... Welles' wife, AMY, smiles when she sees him.  She's plain and pretty, holding one hand on a BABY STROLLER beside he Welles comes to her, embracing her, appreciating her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how much I missed you? They kiss, but Amy pulls away, sniffs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this... have you been smoking... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoking?  I'm not smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your clothing reeks of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Amy, I've been sitting around in bars and everywhere following this guy... I mean, is this what I get first thing?  Before you even "hello," you accuse me... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not accusing you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not smoking, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been all through that.  I've been on my best behavior. Welles bends to the stroller, picks up his infant daughte CINDY, and hoists her in the air, overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, pumpkin-head, did you miss me?  I sure missed you...  He kisses the happy child, holding her in one arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get my bags and get the hell out of here.  Welles pulls Amy close and kisses her again, leads the wa Amy follows, pushing the stroller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the detective business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business was fine.  I'll tell you what, you couldn't pay me enough to live down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not be smoking, that's all I can say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm not, please...  Amy takes Welles hand, smiling at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and Amy make love in the darkness.  Standard, missionary position sex, little passion.  They slow to a finish, uneventfully, holding each other.  Their breathin quiets.  Their daughter CINDY can be HEARD CRYING elsewhe Welles kisses his wife again, rolls off of her and sits o the edge of the bed.  Amy covers herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.  He looks towards her in the dark.  He gets up, gets a tow from the bathroom and wraps it around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy's crying.  Welles enters, goes to lean into the cri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all the trouble, Cinderella? What are you crying about, huh?  He lifts and cradles Cindy, comforting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small city of moderate architecture facing the Susqueha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old money office with windows over the river.  A well- do POLITICIAN looks unhappily through PHOTOS on his desk. Welles sits by the Pennsylvania state flag, watching. PHOTOS show the Young Republican and Gaudy Woman in Miami leaving the Art Deco hotel, the Discotheque, a restaurant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son-in-law dealt with the dry cleaning franchise during the day, saw that woman every night.  (clears his throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The specifics are in the report, and information about the woman.  It's unpleasant, I know.  I apologize...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None too discreet, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, he is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an imbecile.  I tried to warn my daughter, but what can you do?  The politician shakes his head in disgust.  Welles rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The um... you'll find my invoice in the envelope. If that's all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mister Welles, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Senator.  If I can ever be of further assistance. Welles leaves, glances back, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles drives his plain Ford past the CAPITAL BUILDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles' car crosses the Susquehanna, leaving the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunny day.  Welles wears tan khakis, T-shirt and fishing cap, mowing his lawn with his ROARING lawnmower.  Welles' yard is modest, surrounding his modest split level suburb one in a neighborhood of similar homes and similar yards. Welles turns the lawnmower, stopping to mop his brow.  On of his neighbors is repainting a back porch.  The neighbo waves.  Welles waves, resumes mowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC'S LOUD.  League Night.  Every lane full.  Welles is with his team in BOWLING SHIRTS.  Welles hoists his ball, preparing to bowl.  He takes three steps, releases... Down the lane, PINS SCATTER.  One pin remains standing. Welles balls up his fists and curses, walks back towards rowdy, mocking teammates.  He shouts back at them, laughi grabbing his beer and drinking, waiting at the ball retur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner.  Welles and Amy eat at the kitchen table with Cin in a high chair.  Amy feeds Cindy between bites.  Welles still in his league shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you'll have time for the water heater this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  I'll call the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not using the same guy who tried to fix it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not using him again for anything.  He was worthless.  (eating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have bridge here Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's out of town so we're playing next week.  Welles nods, eating.  He watches Amy feed Cindy.  The PHO starts RINGING.  Welles goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  Yes... could you hold on a minute...? Welles hands the phone to Amy, pats Cindy's head as he he downstairs, through the LIVING ROOM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles enters his well kept OFFICE, turns on a light at t desk.  The room is filled with FILE CABINETS and shelves BOOKS, hundreds of PHONE BOOKS and a COPY MACHINE.  Welle picks up the phone and cups the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts upstairs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I've got it. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... sorry, I was switching phones.  It's a pleasure to make your acquaintance, Mrs. Christian. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yes, I understand... tomorrow evening should be fine... Welles listens, clears space on his desk, taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge OLD WORLD MANSION is situated at the center of acr of Pennsylvania forest and vast gardens.  Welles' car hea down a long tree lined drive, to the dark mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles follows a BUTLER down a long hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler shows Welles in, shuts the door. Towering SHELVES of BOOKS are serviced by ladders.  Far across the room, an old, sad woman, MRS. CHRISTIAN, sits waiting with a tall, thin, sinister ghoul of a LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Welles. You're very prompt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to be. Welles crosses towards them. It takes a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your coming on such short notice.  Mrs. Christian holds out her hand and Welles takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mister Longdale, my late husband's attorney.  Welles shakes Longdale's limp hand, looking him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh, pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently Mr. Longdale has something he feels he simply must say before you and I speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do have something to say.  I insisted on being here as soon as I heard Mrs. Christian contacted you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mr. Christian's attorney and one of the executors of his estate, it concerns me that a meeting of this sort should take place without my being asked to attend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what sort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a private investigator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whatever reasons Mrs. Christian has for engaging the services of a private investigator, I should certainly be a party to. But, since she feels differently, I can only go on the record as having expressed my adamant disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, how theatrical.  So you've gone on the record, and now perhaps you should just be gone.  Longdale's irritated, but has no choice.  He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant evening.  (to Welles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you have tea, Mister Welles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Mrs. Christian begins pouring tea from the service on a table.  Welles watches Longdale exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a lawyer. (offers tea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sit, here... Welles accepts a dainty tea cup and saucer, taking a seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've spoken to friends of mine and my husband's, in Harrisburg, in Lancaster and Hershey.  Asking about you.  I must say you have friends in influential places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been privileged to provide services for people I admire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are highly recommended.  Praised for your discretion... your strict adherence to confidentiality.  Welles nods, sipping tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, my husband passed away recently.  Two weeks ago now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My condolences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His passing has left me with... something of a dilemma.  A terrible, terrible dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever I can to help.  Mrs. Christian studies Welles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Christian and Welles enter.  This office has been li in for a lifetime.  Giant DESK.  AMERICAN FLAG.  Walls covered in old b+w PHOTOGRAPHS and ACHIEVEMENTS. A large, baked enamel sign nailed up, "CHRISTIAN STEEL."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His inner sanctum.  Welles looks up at the OIL PAINTING over the fireplace: M CHRISTIAN, a powerful, old man, posed with a dark, teemin industrial landscape behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many people have been inside this room.  Welles examines PHOTOS of Mr. Christian visiting various STEEL PLANTS, COAL MINES and ground-breaking ceremonies, shaking hands with WORKMEN, with POLITICIANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly.  That's where he started his empire building. (looks up at portrait)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a good man.  Notorious as an eccentric, but that was something he cultivated.  He wanted to be legendary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He succeeded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were married forty-five years. Hard even for me to imagine.  We had our troubles.  There were plenty of places for him to be other than here, but he was always loyal to me, and I to him.  I loved him deeply. Welles waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you carry a gun, Mr. Welles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wear a gun when I can tell a client expects me to.  Other than that, there's never any reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just curious.  Mrs. Christian crosses to take down a PICTURE, revealing WALL SAFE.  The safe is ajar, burnt and scarred, broken i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband was the only one with the combination to this safe.  I knew about it, but as far as I was concerned it was none of my business.  Not till now, that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hired someone to open it.  I'll bet the lawyer loved that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was nothing he could do.  My husband left everything to me. (looks at safe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prevented anyone from seeing the contents.  I felt these were my husband's private things.  I didn't... I didn't realize...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to tell me what you found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash, stock certificates, and this... She takes something from her pocket, puts it on the desk: plastic bag containing a short 8MM FILM on a plastic reel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a film... of a girl being murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a movie showing a girl being murdered.  She's sitting on a bed, and a man rapes her... and he begins to cut her with a knife... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only watched what I could. Welles picks up the film, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know what to think.  I can't tell you how horrible it's been, to know this belonged to my husband.  To know that he watched this... this atrocity.  But, I can't go to the police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Christian... please, will you sit down a moment?  (leads her to a chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to listen carefully. What you're talking about is a "snuff film."  But, from what I know, snuff films are a kind of... urban myth.  Like, red light district folklore.  There's no such thing, I can assure you.  Mrs. Christian shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, believe me.  This is probably a stag film.  Simulated rape.  Hard to stomach, and it might seem real, but there are ways of making it look realistic... fake blood and special effects...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to study it you'd see the camera cutting away... you'd see the tricks they can play...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you it's not that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it is.  (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably something your husband was given as a bad joke.  More than likely he never even watched it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you watch it and see for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  But, I'm certain it's nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 8MM PROJECTOR faces a wall.  Welles looks back to Mrs. Christian in the doorway.  Mrs. Christian leaves, shuts t door.  Darkness.  Welles turns on the projector and sits. The PROJECTOR CLATTERS, shooting bright images... ON THE WALL: FLASH FRAMES, over exposure, then... the gra FILM is HAND HELD, constantly in motion, showing a skinny GIRL, 16 or 17, in a negligee, sitting on a bed in a nondescript room with little furniture.  Looks like a hot room.  We only ever see three walls.  The once beautiful girl looks worn, drugged, dark circles under her eyes, staring blankly.  The CAMERA'S tungsten SPOTLIGHT casts long, shifting shadows as the camera moves, but the girl still stares oblivious.  The bed is wrapped in PLASTIC an DUCT TAPE.  The floor is covered by PLASTIC SHEETING... Welles watches, crossing his arms, already uncomfortable. ON THE WALL: a door opens behind the girl, looks like a bathroom, and a MASKED MAN enters. The Masked Man wears a garish, Mexican WRESTLING MASK wit eye holes and a mouth.  The mask covers his entire head. He's naked except for red shorts, his body scrawny, oiled pale.  The man goes to stand in front of the girl.  He se to be saying something to her, but the film is silent and the ONLY SOUND is the PROJECTOR'S LOUD sprocket hole CLATTER.  It's all one long take.  The CAMERA MOVES to fa the girl... Welles sits straight in his chair, wary. ON THE WALL: Masked Man raises his open hand and SLAPS th girl, knocking her back on the bed... Welles grimaces. ON THE WALL: Masked Man pulls the girl back to a seated position.  The girl's like a rag doll, face reddened, eye closed, but she remains upright.  Masked Man uses his thu to open her unseeing eyes.  He touches her mouth with his fingers, presses his lips to hers.  Then, Masked Man back away, leaving frame, till the CAMERA MOVES to find Masked Man standing at a table with THREE large BOWIE KNIFES lai out.  Masked Man runs his fingers over the blades... Welles rises slowly, still watching. ON THE WALL: Masked Man selects a huge Bowie knife and mo back towards the girl... Welles crosses his arms tight, disbelieving, fearful. WE WILL NEVER SEE WHAT HAPPENS NEXT IN THE FILM, but Well does.  In the flickering, reflected light, Welles backs involuntarily away from the horrible images, holding his fist to his mouth, breathing hard. Welles keeps backing away, till he's backed against a wal The PROJECTOR'S CLATTERING.  Welles is sickened, sweating still watching, till he finally shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  Mrs. Christian sits waiting, troubled. The door to the dining room opens and Welles enters from dark, visibly shaken.  Mrs. Christian watches him, her sorrow now shared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... you need to go to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I can't, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have any other choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands, shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  For me to live with the ruin of my husband's name, I need know that whoever did this will be punished. If you can find them, I will take their names to the police.  I'll say my husband confessed on his death bed. I'll say I didn't have courage to come forward at first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't work like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any evidence you collect can be given to the police later, anonymously.  I've thought about it and there's no other way.  If you can't find them... if the only thing that comes from this film is that this is all my husband will be remembered for, well I can't let that happen.  I'm telling you I won't.  If there's no chance that poor girl's memory can be served, then I'll just have to spend my last days trying to forget her.  Welles sits, rests his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deal in divorce cases.  Corporate investigations...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've found missing persons before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing remotely like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm asking.  Your compensation will be appropriate to the risk.  You'll need cash to buy information, and I'll provide it. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel responsible, Mr. Welles. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw what he did to her. Welles stands, torn apart and uncertain, looks back to th dining room where the projector sits idle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy is sound asleep in her crib. Welles is seated near, staring at his sleeping child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles digs in piles of SHOEBOXES and BOOKS on the floor his cluttered closet, finds what he wants: a LOCK BOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles twists the lock box dial's combination, opens the to reveal his GUN, HOLSTER and CLEANING SUPPLIES.  Welles takes out the gun, cleaning it.  Amy watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the mortgage.  This is Cindy's college money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you can't know what I'm doing.  It's better that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a missing persons case... a long shot.  I'll give it two months, two months at most, then I'll be back.  We'll take a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna need it.  I won't even wear it.  It's a precaution. (cleaning gun)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles looks through one file cabinet.  He pulls out a FI It contains all sorts of POLICE ARTIST SKETCHES.  Welles finds one of a TEENAGE GIRL with dark hair, looks at it. Welles positions the sketch on his COPY MACHINE, hits cop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles loads BOXES and a SUITCASE into his car's back sea Welles puts the lock box in the car's trunk, in a hiding place beside the spare tire.  He places a brown BRIEFCASE top, covers them both with carpet.  He closes the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little traffic.  Welles' Ford races down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: City skyline, overcast.  Looks like rain. TITLE:       Cleveland, Ohio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles' car moves slowly in a not-so-great neighborhood. Welles leans forward, peering through the windshield... An APARTMENT BUILDING'S crooked SIGN lists "WEEKLY RATES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dingy room.  Welles locks the door, puts the chain on. Hi suitcase and boxes are on the bed.  He begins unpacking, taking a PHOTO ENLARGER from one box and an 8MM PROJECTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The developer's on the toilet.  DEVELOPING PANS are on th floor, developer bath, stop bath and fixing bath, with BOTTLES of CHEMICALS and packages of PHOTO PAPER.  Welles uses tape and ALUMINUM FOIL to black-out a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pizza box on the bedside table.  Welles' suits hang in th closet.  Welles sits facing a small REEL TO REEL on a des He wears white gloves, handles the 8MM FILM, careful to h it by the edges, holding it up to the light, squinting. Welles puts in a magnifying EYEPIECE, leaning close... WELLES' P.O.V. THROUGH MAGNIFYING LENS: studying the firs few inches of exposed film, coming upon TINY LETTERS prin just below the sprocket holes: "SUPRAlux 544."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED BULB in the light socket.  Welles threads the 8MM FIL into his enlarger, still in white gloves. He flicks the enlarger on, projecting a sideways IMAGE do onto the enlarger's baseboard, FOCUSING... it's the girl sitting on the bed, early in the snuff film. Welles makes an adjustment to the enlarger's lens; framin tighter on the girl's face, REFOCUSING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles comes out of the makeshift darkroom, holding a PHO of the girl.  He props the photo up on a dresser, stands looking at it.  Sad girl, staring forward. Welles goes to pick up his CELLULAR PHONE, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, honey, it's me. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, how are you? Welles listens.  He turns to look at the girl's photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nondescript.  "U.S. Resource Center for Missing Persons."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small.  Cubicles.  Employees work phones and computers. BULLETIN BOARDS are covered in FAMILY PHOTOS, Polaroids a familiar "HAVE YOU SEEN ME?" missing person/children POST IN ONE CUBICLE, Welles opens his billfold, shows his identification: a laminated "LICENSED INVESTIGATOR, Commonwealth of Pennsylvania", with WELLES' PHOTO... The DIRECTOR of the center, a tired looking official in bifocals, studies the card.  Welles sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Mr. Welles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'd like, very simply, is access to your archive.  And, now I understand this isn't something you normally do for private citizens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are reasons for the way we do things here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.  Of course I'll abide by whatever decision you make, but I'd appreciate if you'll hear me out...  The director sits back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few days ago, I was contacted by a couple living in Philadelphia, a doctor and his wife.  What happened was they picked up a young girl hitchhiking off 81, which heads into Philadelphia, started up a conversation with this girl, she looked homeless, seemed about eighteen maybe.  They convinced her to let them buy her a meal in the city.  Nice kid, mature, didn't have much to say, but they got a sense she's a runaway, so all through dinner the doctor's working on her, trying to convince her that at the very least she should pick up a telephone.  Not surprisingly, she ate her food, excused herself... (snaps fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last they saw her.  The reason they came to me for help, the reason I'm coming to you, is we had a friend of mine in the department work up a sketch... (shows the POLICE ARTIST SKETCH he photocopied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want to see if I can I.D. this girl, somehow pass along a message to let the parents know the kid's alive, doing alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not go to the N.C.I.C. or

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured you share information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For whatever reasons I thought you might be more receptive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't they come to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doctor and wife, they're nice people, but they don't want to get too involved.  They're not trying to have the parents come looking for the girl either.  You and I both know sometimes, not often, but sometimes there's real reasons why a kid'll run.  Molestation, whatever.  Besides that, the girl's probably eighteen, so she's legal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're putting themselves in place of this kid's parents and thinking they'd want to hear their girl's okay, even if that's all they hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you my card, if your clients want to call me...  Welles accepts a CARD, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were pretty clear they didn't want this coming back on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's all I can do.  Sorry.  Welles looks at the director, stands, hangs his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows... maybe she's already given her parents a call, right? Welles leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles comes out the front doors, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. He tears the card in half and drops it as he heads for hi car.  After a moment, the director comes out after him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Tom, hold on... Welles looks back, walks back, glances down... makes sure he stands on the torn card, hiding it underfoo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, maybe I can help after all. Why don't you come on back in... we'll see what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director leads Welles into this RESEARCH ROOM, a small library with long tables, old COMPUTERS, lots of FILE CABINETS and CARD CATALOGS.  Secretaries tend to the file

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.  It's not much.  (points at computers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got less than five percent on computer and we lose that funding in December.  I'll have someone show it to you anyway.  Other than that, I'm afraid it's the wet thumb method. Welles looks to the many, many file drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Files are mostly by state and year of disappearance.  We try to keep the children and adults separate. No eating or smoking in here, but there's a coffee machine in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's horrible, but it'll be your best friend after a few days.  I hope you realize what kind of long shot you're chasing after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna be seeing a lot of me. You're sure you don't mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good what you're doing. The director puts out his hand.  Welles looks, shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A COMPUTER SCREEN: files open and close -- PICTURE aft PICTURE of a MISSING CHILDREN, mostly teenagers, each wit physical description, age, date of disappearance, etc.  L souls, although these are posed portraits, high school yearbook photos and vacation photos, so the children are mostly smiling, happy and healthy. But, all "MISSING." Welles works the computer keyboard and mouse... ON THE SCREEN: the FACES of TEENAGERS, boys and girls, on after the other, MISSING... MISSING... MISSING...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles searches the SHELVES of the LIBRARY.  He begins taking down various books... "Motion Picture Photography."  "Film Stocks and Physical Characteristics."  "Super 8 Filmmaking."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Welles' notepad: "SUPRAlux 544." Welles sits paging through technical photography books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles has the 8MM FILM threaded through the projector. turns the CLATTERING projector on and sits, watching. ON THE WALL: FLASH FRAMES, then... the skinny GIRL in a negligee, sitting on the bed.  The CAMERA'S SPOTLIGHT cas long shadows.  The girl stares, oblivious... ON THE WALL: a door opens behind the girl, looks like a bathroom, and the MASKED MAN enters, wearing the ghastly WRESTLING MASK.  The man goes to stand in front of the girl.  He seems to be saying something.  The FILM halts. Welles sits forward, hand on the projector.  He's seen something.  He PLAYS the FILM in REVERSE... ON THE WALL: the Masked Man walks backwards, away from th girl, backwards into the bathroom, door shutting... Welles stops the projector, not taking his eyes from the image.  He ADVANCES the film FRAME BY FRAME... FRAME BY FRAME... as the bathroom door opens, and the Mas Man enters... FRAME BY FRAME... as the Masked Man moves forward... door closing behind him... STOP... FREEZE FRAME: a THIRD MAN is reflected in the bathroom mirror.  Grainy and blurred, but he's in the room with th girl, standing there, captured in the mirror in this one brief instant just before the bathroom door closes. Welles walks to take a closer look, studying the almost ethereal image of the Third Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is in a PHONE BOOTH, feeds many quarters into the phone, waiting, looking at his notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Christian?  Tom Welles. Here's where we stand.  I checked the film stock and it's called Supra- lux 544.  The company that made that stock discontinued it in '92... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, about five or six years ago. Anyway, do what you can to dig up your husband's old financial records, look for anything out of the ordinary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is back at the computer, alone, drinking coffee. ON THE COMPUTER: endless PHOTOS of MISSING CHILDREN. The PHONE CALL CONTINUES in VOICE OVER: WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody really uses eight millimeter film anymore, so we can assume there are reasons our guys did.  First, they could develop it themselves if they had any sort of expertise. Obviously, this isn't the kind of movie you can just drop off at the one-hour photo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles just stands, staring at the PHOTO of the GIRL. WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second, the film that went through the camera is what we've got. There's no negative.  Unlike video, it wasn't meant to be duplicated. No reason for them to risk having more than one copy of their murder floating around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local bar.  Welles sits drinking with the archive's director, talking, smiling at something the director said WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There don't seen to be many fingerprints on the film itself, but I'm going to have to be careful to leave them intact...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is tired, unshaven.  He's moved on to the physical files, at one table, looking through HUNDREDS of MISSING PERSON BULLETINS.  Secretaries tend to other files.  WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay for yours and your husbands fingerprints to be on the film, but you'll have to use me as a middleman if you go to the police. That way I don't have to explain why my prints are on it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits with the PROJECTOR ON, watching the film agai WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were three men.  Two are obvious; the man in the mask and the man running the camera, but I caught a glimpse of a third man in a mirror.  It's nothing that can be used for identification, but he was there, watching... ON THE WALL: Masked Man touches the girl's mouth, presses his lips to hers.  Masked Man backs away, leaving frame, till the CAMERA MOVES to find Masked Man standing at a ta with THREE large BOWIE KNIFES laid out... Welles notices something, puts the projector on FREEZE FR WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, there were three.  They would have kept it small, wouldn't have let anyone in on it they didn't have to.  That's all for now... except, I feel I should tell you... with this looking like it happened at least five or six years ago... Welles walks to the frozen IMAGE on the wall.  It shows t Masked Man's hands in frame, fingering the blades. WELLES (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not very likely we'll ever find out who this girl was.  (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, I'll keep trying. Goodbye. V.O. PHONE CALL ends with the SOUND of the PHONE HANGING ON THE WALL: there's a DARK SPOT on Masked Man's hand, on the arch between his index finger and thumb.  Grainy and hard to make out, but looks like a small TATTOO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles has the 8MM FILM threaded into his photo enlarger, projecting the IMAGE we just saw down onto the baseboard. He re-frames, CLOSER ON the masked Man's hand, REFOCUSING the black spot is a little clearer, looks like a small ST tattoo on the back of Masked Man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits hunched over the card catalog, still unshaven drinking coffee, flipping through smaller PICTURES of MISSING CHILDREN in one drawer, one by one by one... Welles rolls his neck.  He looks to see the archive's director in the doorway.  The director nods, leaving. Welles gets back to it, stooped over the catalog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD:      three weeks later

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the lot, Welles gets wearily from his car, smoking.  H tosses the cigarette, gets a Thermos off the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles pulls out a card catalog drawer labeled "North Carolina 1992," flipping through picture cards.  The FACE of TEENAGERS: a happy BOY with blue eyes... a red headed GIRL with freckles... a ruddy faced BOY... a pretty GIRL with a ribbon in her hair... a black GIRL in a pink dress a blonde haired BOY with curly hair... Welles furrows his brow. He backtracks to the pretty GIRL with the ribbon in her h Welles sits straight.  He reaches into his pocket, hands shaking a little, takes out and unfolds the PHOTO he prin of the girl from the snuff film.  It's her. Welles compares the two pictures.  She's prettier in the card catalog photo, but it's her. Welles can't believe it, looks around.  Secretaries at ot files don't even know he's there.  Welles pulls out his notepad, scribbling down INFORMATION off the card... Writing the girl's name: "Mary Anne Matthews."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles, car races past, alone on the dark freeway.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Another small city.  Blue skies above. TITLE:     Fayetteville, North Carolina

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Suburban library.  Kids play hop-scotch in the parking lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles works the MICROFICHE MACHINE, scrolling through ol issues of the LOCAL NEWSPAPER, finds an ARTICLE headlined "Search Continues for Local Teen." There's a PICTURE of the GIRL, Mary Anne Mathews; the sam picture Welles found in the Missing Person Archive. Welles reads the article, writing on a LEGAL PAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEWSPRINT SCROLLS past on the MICROFICHE MACHINE, till... "No Leads in Girl's Disappearance."  Same picture. The date at the top: "July 12, 1992."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEWSPRINT BLURS past... stops on a page of OBITUARIES. Top of the page: "September 4, 1993." CLOSE ON: "Mathews, Robert Steven, 1948-1993." "Dead in an apparent suicide, Robert Mathews was discover yesterday morning in the basement of..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tree-lined street of poor, boxy homes.  Welles' car par in front of one HOUSE with a neglected lawn.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAR
dialogues.text: Welles, clean shaven, picks a CLIPBOARD with a file folde and his legal pad on it, thumbs pages.  He drums his fingers, opens the glove compartment, pulls out the car's registration, other papers and "Jiffy-Lube" service repor uses them to pad the file. Welles takes a BOTTLE of COLOGNE from his pocket.  He considers it, opens the bottle, applies cologne to his ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles knocks, clipboard in hand.  A sad, middle-aged wom answers, MRS. MATHEWS, looking through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Mathews, my name's Thomas Jones, I'm a state licensed investigator... Welles holds up his identification only long enough for M Mathews to see it looks official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been hired as an independent contractor by the U.S. Resource Center for Missing Persons as part of an internal audit.  If you have any time over the next few days, I'd like to make an appointment to ask some questions about the disappearance of your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, who are... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, let me explain, the R.C.M.P. is a support organization and archive, not unlike the Center for Missing and Exploited Children in Washington.  I'm sure you've dealt with them before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These volunteer organizations are sort of interconnected, functioning hand in hand with law enforcement. The R.C.M.P. brought me in to review their investigations... (holds up clipboard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... fact-check their records, see if there's anything they missed, anything they should be doing different.  I'm here for a few days, before I head back up to Virginia. These reports go to the Justice Department eventually.  I spoke to your F.B.I. contact a few days ago, uh... Welles pretends to look for the name on a Jiffy Lube page

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was the name... ? I've got it here somewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil... Neil Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretends he found it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Agent Cole told me he'd call and let you know to expect me.  He didn't call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking on legal pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm following up on your daughter, Mary, height; five four, weight; hundred ten pounds, brown eyes, blonde hair.  Born April 24, 1976.  Missing June 11th, 1992.  A runaway, that's how she's listed. Is this information correct... ? Mrs. Mathews stares, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I know this isn't easy. Is there a more convenient time... ? (looks at watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I buy you lunch, would that be alright? Mrs. Mathews looks him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and Mrs. Mathews eat at a PICNIC TABLE on the pati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very important you don't let this raise your expectations.  It's not going to effect any ongoing efforts.  All I'm saying is, please know, I'm not here to create any false hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hired you.  You're like, a private detective?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I am. Mrs. Mathews chews, staring off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think there were private detectives anymore, except on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably expect me to be wearing a trench coat and a hat.  Drinking whiskey, chasing women and getting beaten up by guys with broken noses. Want to know what it's really like?  It's sitting in a car and staring at a hotel window for three days straight, pissing in a plastic bottle, pardon me, because some guy thinks his wife's cheating on him. Glamorous, huh?  And the guy who hired you, he has a hair-lip, dandruff and crooked teeth, and you could have told him the minute you laid eyes on him his wife's cheating, and you don't blame her. Mrs. Mathews smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's refreshing to actually sit down and meet someone face to face, someone nice like you. Welles smiles.  Mrs. Mathews takes out a cigarette.  Well lights her, joins her in smoking, refers to his clipboard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, she didn't leave a note?  She never gave any indication where she might go, before she left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just seemed... depressed... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't seem herself.  For months there never was any way to get her to talk about it.  One night we went to bed... the next morning she was gone.  She took some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was she running from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything you feel uncomfortable talking about, tell me, but I have to ask.  Your husband... he committed suicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 4th, 1993.  About a year after Mary disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were divorced by then.  Things fell apart... he was living with a friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think he did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got to be too much for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to forgive me, but in these circumstances... with your daughter... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were there any indications of... any sort of abuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't anything like that. The police and the FBI people asked, but there wasn't anything happened like that, never.  My husband... his heart broke when Mary left...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You try going through what we did. Bob couldn't take it, that's all. Christ, there's times when it still seems like I can't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to ask.  I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows what it's like.  You can't even imagine how much it hurts.  Welles is miserable.  A few CUSTOMERS walk past, looking Mrs. Mathews.  She tries not to notice then noticing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People remember me from the news. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you drive me back now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mathews enters.  Welles follows.  This was the girl's room, exactly as she left it -- POSTE of ACTORS on the wall, many STUFFED ANIMALS on the pink sheets of the carefully made bed.  Perfectly preserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is her room. Welles looks around, uncomfortable. Shelves have PICTURES of MARY with female friends, a collection of CERAMIC FIGURINES of CLOWNS and ANIMALS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police made a wreck of it, but I put it back exactly how it was. Just how she likes it. Welles takes a few steps into the room, looks down at a D where there are SIX brightly wrapped GIFTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are for her birthday.  One for every year she's missed.  They'll be waiting for her when she comes back.  Welles is nearly overwhelmed by sadness, struggling to hi it.  He backs to the door, looks at his watch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I shouldn't take anymore of your time.  Maybe we can finish tomorrow.  I'll call tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles escapes to his car, climbing in.  He starts it up.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAR
dialogues.text: Welles drives, tears welling up in his eyes.  He has to p over and park, wiping his tears, fighting for composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles has unpacked.  He's on the bed, on his CELLULAR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be able to take a shower and still have hot water left, honey. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call him back and tell him I said so.  The goddamn thing's still under warranty. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.  It's hard here.  It's hard. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a lead I have to follow through.  To be honest, I don't think I'm going to get very far. I miss you.  I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits at the kitchen table.  Mrs. Mathews makes coffee.  The home's decor is cheap and flowery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren't religious.  We never forced religion down her throat, like I've seen some parents do to their kids.  We never made her go to church.  But, after Mary was gone, that's when I got religious. Mrs. Mathews brings two cups of coffee, sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't make much sense, does it? When everything's happy, when life's fine and you have every reason to believe there's a God, you don't bother.  Then, something horrible happens... that's when you start praying all the time.  That's when you start going to church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you religious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be. Mrs. Mathews drinks coffee, stares into the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got what I need for my report. There is... there is one thing that bothers me though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not really my place, but it's not easy for me to set aside the private detective part of me either. See, I know a little about missing persons.  When kids run, they almost always leave a note.  It's guilt. They want to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't one.  The police looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think the police did a good job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is possible... and I know this isn't something you want to hear. Your daughter may have tried to hide a note where she thought you would eventually find it, but where she knew your husband would never find it.  She might have wanted to tell you something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You don't have any reason to think that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the police focused their search in her room, her belongings, well that'd be only natural, but they may have been looking in the wrong place. Mrs. Mathews is getting upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How... how can you say that to me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you let me look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband never laid a hand on her. She would have told me... she would have told me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably right, and I probably won't find anything. I don't have a right to ask this, and you can kick me out of your house if you want, but this is my profession and there's a part of me that can't let it go.  Police are just as human as you or I.  They could have missed something.  They probably didn't. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you rather know? Mrs. Mathews thinks about it, tortured, shakes her head s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and look if you want.  I don't care what you do. Mrs. Mathews gets up and walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: -In MRS. MATHEWS' BEDROOM, Welles looks through DRESSER drawers, methodically, replacing everything as it was... searches hat boxes and shoe boxes in a CLOSET... takes BOOKS off SHELVES, fanning the pages, shaking them out... -In a BATHROOM, Welles examines the contents of a MEDICIN CABINET, examining old prescription bottles... opens CABINETS under the sink... -In the LIVING ROOM, Mrs. Mathews sits slumped in a chair staring at a soap opera on TELEVISION, a BOTTLE of scotch on TV tray beside her, drink in hand. -In the KITCHEN, Welles stands on a chair, searches high CABINETS... looks through low CABINETS, on his knees, pul out pots and pans... fans the pages of COOK BOOKS... -Welles stands in the doorway of MARY'S ROOM, just stares He takes a few steps back into the HALLWAY, looks up at t ceiling.  There's an ATTIC DOOR there.  Welles reaches to the door's handle, opens it, unfolds the portable stairs. -In the small ATTIC, Welles uses a penlight FLASHLIGHT, crouched under the low ceiling, looking through dusty BOX of PHOTOGRAPHS; old photos of a wedding, of grandparents. Welles moves to pull back dusty sheets, finds a large WICKER BASKET and broken BICYCLE underneath... Welles opens the basket, takes out BLANKETS and QUILTS in mothballs.  He finds a wide VELVET BOX, takes it out, opens its hinged lid to reveal a set of good SILVERWARE. He touches the tarnished silverware, lifts out the top tr Underneath, resting on top of more silverware, is a DIARY Welles opens the DIARY, finds written: "Mary Anne Mathews Welles turns pages.  The DIARY'S about half-full of feminine, cursive handwriting.  After the last written page, a PAGE has been TORN OUT.  Welles fingers the ragge edge, flips through the blank pages till he comes to the very last page, a GOODBYE NOTE.  Welles sits and reads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emotionless monotone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear mom.  If you're reading this, it means I called you from Hollywood, California and told you where to find my diary.  I don't think I'll be able to tell you this when I talk to you, so I'm writing it down here.  You know I haven't been happy for a long, long time. For a long time now dad's been doing things I couldn't tell you.  He's been touching me and it's getting worse.  I can't stay anymore.  I know you and I haven't always gotten along sometimes, but please don't blame yourself.  There isn't anything you can do.  I'm going to make a whole new life in California. Maybe someday you'll see me on TV or in magazines.  Don't worry about me. Love, Mary Anne."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles shuts the attic door, takes the DIARY from his pocket, hides it in his waistband at the small of his bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles enters.  Mrs. Mathews looks up from the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't find anything.  I'm going to run and get something to eat. Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles uses a self-serve COPY MACHINE, flattening the DIA on the glass, photocopying the DIARY as quickly as he can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits picking at fast food in front of him.  Mrs. Mathews' food isn't even unwrapped.  She's numb from her drink, watching a GAME SHOW, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever consider... do you realize that Mary may never come back? Mrs. Mathews looks to Welles, looks back at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about it everyday.  But, every time the phone rings... every single time, I still think it's her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been six years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?  Forget her?  Time heals all wounds, right? (misery building)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all I think about, and I've learned to live with that.  But, you want the truth... the real truth? If I had a choice... if I had to choose, between her being out there, living a good life and being happy, and me not knowing; never finding out what happened to her... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... or her being dead and me knowing... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd choose to know. Mrs. Mathews stares into the TV, wipes tears. Welles takes a deep breath and holds it.  He watches her long moment, motionless.  Finally he stands, voice unstea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I have to use your bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles comes to the attic door, quietly pulls it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles uses his penlight, digs out the DIARY from the hid place in his waistband, replaces it in the box of silverware, closes the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles enters, takes a PICTURE FRAME off one shelf, opens the back and takes out the PHOTO of MARY from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mathews still gazes into the TV.  Welles passes the doorway, not looking in, heading to the front door, openi the door and walking out... Mrs. Mathews doesn't even notice, doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles crosses the front lawn, not looking back, heading the street, getting into his car, starting his car, doing U-turn, driving away down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles' boxes of belongings are piled in the back seat of his car.  Welles covers them with a blanket, shuts the do Welles opens the trunk of his car, pulls back the carpeti He opens the brown BRIEFCASE.  The briefcase is full of CASH, about $10,000, twenties and fifties in bundles. Welles transfers half the money into a carry-on bag, shut the briefcase, covers it, closes the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabin's half-full, dark.  Passengers sleep.  Under th only illuminated reading light, Welles reads the PHOTOCOP DIARY.  MARY'S VOICE is a again a flat monotone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Welles reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  I have a big math test tomorrow.  I have to get better grades.  How come everybody does better than me?  Kathy doesn't even study and she gets B's.  Two boys got in a fight after school today. One boy knocked the other boy's tooth out, at least that's what it looked like.  His nose and mouth were bleeding all over the place..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An airplane ROARS downwards, heading in for a landing.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: An ugly city.  "HOLLYWOOD" sign on the smoggy horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheap, stucco hotel in a wounded Hollywood neighborhood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles' suitcase is open on the bed.  Welles sits in a ch with his feet up, sweating in the heat, reading the DIARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Welles reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... We're reading The Great Gatsby in English class.  It's the story of this guy who has lots of fancy parties and all his friends come around and party with him, but later when he dies nobody comes to his funeral.  Someone said there's a movie about it, but I looked in the video store and it wasn't there." Welles flips pages, further back in the DIARY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Welles reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  I started my first job last week working part time at Price Mart department store..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles and a BANK EMPLOYEE both put keys into a SAFE DEPO BOX, unlocking it and sliding out the metal drawer. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... The people I work with are all old and fat.  All they live for is their next coffee break so they can smoke..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is alone, opens the empty safe deposit drawer, tak the 8MM FILM from his pocket and puts it in the drawer. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... They eat lunch at the snack counter.  Hot dogs and soft pretzels.  Nachos with that orange cheese that comes out of a pump.  I don't know what I'd do if I'm still working there when I get old..."

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A large NEON CROSS identifies this HOSTEL in mid-Hollywoo MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... I want to be a singer or an actress.  I know it's a stupid dream, but I know I can do it if I get a chance..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles talks to the MAN behind the counter, shows the PICTURE of MARY taken from Mrs. Mathews' house. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... Everyone's always telling me how pretty I am.  I don't think I am.  When I look in the mirror I wonder who they're talking about." The MAN behind the counter shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run-down shelter.  Welles shows the PICTURE of MARY to PROPRIETOR, explaining.  The proprietor shakes his head. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  I went out with Bob today, the cute boy in my science class.  He took me to a movie..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles continues his trek, standing in the dank hallway o a YWCA DORMITORY, showing the PICTURE to a COUNSELOR. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... It was the middle of the day, but we held hands.  I think he likes me.  I really like him.  He has black hair and grey eyes..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sits in his rental CAR, in a massive TRAFFIC JAM. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... He opened the car door for me and paid for the movie.  When he took me home he said we should go out again soon.  I hope he calls..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles drives, looking out the windshield... at decaying "PEEP SHOWS," an "ADULT BOOKSHOP" and "SEX SH MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  Janet says she slept with her boyfriend.  I can't believe it.  She says they did it last weekend while her parents were out of town..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles drives, watching overweight PROSTITUTES and tall, muscular TRANSVESTITES prowling the sidewalks in mini-ski and stained, tight spandex pants. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... She said she liked it, but she didn't seem too happy.  She didn't tell me many details.  She said he used a condom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teenaged MALE PROSTITUTES hang out in front of a PIZZA PARLOR.  A few have their shirts off, crewcut and muscula MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  If I save enough money to go to community college maybe I can get good enough grades for a scholarship somewhere else..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tribe of HOMELESS TEENAGERS sits on the sidewalk in fro of SOUVENIR SHOPS.  They beg money off pedestrians. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... I've never been anywhere else. I don't think mom wants to let me go.  Every time I try to talk about it she says it'll cost too much or she changes the subject."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of HOMELESS PERSONS trails out the door.  Wel stands out front, showing the PICTURE to a VOLUNTEER with broom, and a PRIEST... MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  Something terrible happened today when dad and I were alone.  I can't tell anyone.  I feel sick.  What did I ever do to make this happen to me?" The volunteer and priest can't help.  Welles is weary, futility beginning to wear on him, walks to his car... MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  My stomach hurts all the time.  I just want to go to sleep and never wake up.  I want to get out of my head and stop hearing myself think."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles smokes, driving, blankly watching the road ahead.. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  Grandma fell and broke her leg last week.  We drove down to visit her in the hospital. Hospitals smell like dead people."

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: FOLLOW Welles' car speeding along... MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  It's happening all the time now.  There s nothing I can do. I'm all alone.  Everything is bad. I used to have lots of dreams and I'd remember them when I woke up, but that doesn't happen anymore." PULL BACK: still FOLLOWING WELLES' CAR, over the FREEWAY. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear diary.  If I can get to California, I'll be okay.  I've got money saved.  I can work as a waitress till I get something better.  Billy says he and his family went to California once on vacation.  He says it never rains. They stayed near the beach and he went swimming in the ocean..." CONTINUE TO PULL BACK -- till Welles' car is very, very f below -- REVEALING the staggering size of the City of Los Angeles, where the lights go on forever and forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles is seated, elbows on his knees, reading the DIARY. MARY'S VOICE (V.O., cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... I hope I can be an actress.  I hope I can be happy.  I'll probably have to go to acting school.  I wish I knew someone who lived there. I'll miss my friends, but at least I'll be far away where no one can ever find me." Welles has come to the end of the writing in the DIARY. next PHOTOCOPIED PAGE shows an image of the TORN RAGGED E of the diary's missing page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

A few of the other CUSTOMERS, all men, sneak glances at Welles.  Display shelves run floor to ceiling, full of hundreds of shrink- wrapped XXX PORNO TAPES.  Welles pretends to browse. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Max has long hair, colorful tattoos covering his forearms, has a HIGHLIGHTER MARKER in his mouth. Welles browses.  There's a huge video bargain bin.  Walls are covered in videos, sex toys, inflatable women, etc.  CUSTOMERS, again all wary males, follow proper porn-shop etiquette; look at the porn, not your fellow shopper. He goes to the substantial MAGAZINE RACK, picks up a porn tabloid, pages through it.  He sele sex MAGAZINES and NEWSPAPERS, choosing about twenty-five. dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truman Capote.

Turning pages of HARDCORE ADVERTISEMENTS: "Adults Only," "She Male Films," "Amateur Sex Videos," "Women and Animals -- you've got to see it to believe it..." dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through headphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through headphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, if you don't mind me asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's the deal, Max.  This thing I'm on right now has something to do with underground pornography. Stuff that's sold under the counter, illegally...

dialogues.text: You're not a cop, are you?  If I ask and you are, you have to tell me.

dialogues.text: I'm not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Pennsylvania.  P.I. from PA. What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's the thing; you're not gonna know anything about what I'm doing, but you can make some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you make now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred a week, off the books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's pretend I live in the same fantasy world where you make four hundred a week in that dump. I'll give you six hundred for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good, pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my number if you need it... (writes on scrap paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can you start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you then.  Oh, and, don't call me "pops." Welles walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welles sleeps, despite the stead SOUND of TRAFFIC racing his window.  The PHONE RINGS, waking him.  Welles looks a the clock radio, 2:23am, reaches to answer the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Hello... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against the backdrop of downtown LA's bright skyscrapers, Welles' rental car heads into the lower bowels of the cit smaller, older, darker buildings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Max and Welles move through this filth strewn alley betwe decaying brink buildings.  They cone to a STAIRWELL leadi down to pitch dark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a law enforcement... ?

dialogues.text: Max and Welles enter through the double doors, into a kin of small, underground porn flea market.  It's incredibly quiet.  About fifteen CARD TABLES are set up in rows.  Th MEN behind the tables and the thirty or so "CUSTOMERS" looking through the merchandise make those in the previou porn shops look like high society. These are MIDDLE-AGED MEN, most balding, some with pot bellies, in shorts and tube socks, in sweatpants and Memb Only jackets: plain men, but with a look of desperation i their eyes, glancing around nervously, greasy and afraid.

One table is covered in dirty cardboard boxes, filled with HUNDREDS of PHOTOS of young children, mostly boys, naked.  Each photo wrapped in plastic, censored by masking tape.
